column8: Measuring the quality of design pattern detection results
column10: +ACI-2015 IEEE 22nd International Conference on Software Analysis
column43: +ACI-Detecting design patterns in large software systems is a common reverse engineering task that can help the comprehension process of the system's design. While several design pattern detection tools presented in the literature are capable of detecting design patterns automatically
column44: evaluating these detection results is usually done in a manual and subjective fashion. Differences in design pattern definitions
column45: as well as pattern instance counting and presenting
column46: exacerbate the difficulty of evaluating design pattern detection results. In this paper
column47: we present a novel approach to evaluating and comparing design pattern detection results. Our approach
column49: introduces a novel way to present design pattern instances in a uniform fashion. Based on this characterization of design pattern instances
column50: we propose four measures for design pattern detection evaluation that convey a concise assessment of the quality of the results produced by a given detection method. We have implemented these measures
column51: and present case studies that showcase their usefulness. +//0Awv/9AKk- 2015 IEEE.+ACI-

column8: A comprehensive approach to the recovery of design pattern instances based on sub+AC0-patterns and method signatures
column10: Journal of Systems and Software
column40: +ACI-Design patterns are formalized best practices that address concerns related to high+AC0-level structures for applications being developed. The efficient recovery of design pattern instances significantly facilitates program comprehension and software reengineering. However
column41: the recovery of design pattern instances is not a straightforward task. In this paper
column42: we present a novel comprehensive approach to the recovery of instances of 23 GoF design patterns from source codes. The key point of the approach lies in that we consider different design pattern instances consist of some commonly recurring sub+AC0-patterns that are easier to be detected. In addition
column43: we focus not only on the class relationship
column44: but also on the characteristics of underlying method signatures in classes. We first transform the source codes and predefined GoF patterns into graphs
column45: with the classes as nodes and the relationships as edges. We then identify the instances of sub+AC0-patterns that would be the possible constituents of pattern instances by means of subgraph discovery. The sub+AC0-pattern instances are further merged by the joint classes to see if the collective matches one of the predefined patterns. Finally
column46: we compare the behavioral characteristics of method invocation with the predefined method signature templates of GoF patterns to obtain the final pattern instances directly. Compared with existing approaches
column47: we integrate and improve some of the previous ideas and put forward a comprehensive and elaborative approach also based on our own ideas. We detect sub+AC0-patterns via graph isomorphism based on prime number composition and the joint classes to reduce the search space. Meanwhile
column48: we employ the method signatures to investigate the behavioral features to avoid choosing the test cases with full code coverage. The results of the extensive experiments on recovering pattern instances from nine open source software systems demonstrate that our approach obtains the balanced high precision and recall. +//0Awv/9AKk- 2015 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.+ACI-

column78: +ACI-Design patterns are recognized as a means to improve software maintenance by furnishing an explicit specification of class and object interactions and their underlying intent +AFs-Gamma et al. 1995+AF0-. Only a few empirical investigations have been conducted to assess whether the kind of documentation for design patterns implemented in source code affects its comprehensibility. To investigate this aspect
column79: we conducted a family of four controlled experiments with 88 participants having different experience (i.e.
column82: and PhD students). In each experiment
column83: the participants were divided into three groups and asked to comprehend a nontrivial chunk of an open+AC0-source software system. Depending on the group
column86: provided with graphical or textual representations of the design patterns implemented within the source code. We graphically documented design+AC0-pattern instances with UML class diagrams. Textually documented instances are directly reported source code as comments. Our results indicate that documenting design+AC0-pattern instances yields an improvement in correctness of understanding source code for those participants with an adequate level of experience. +//0Awv/9AKk- 2015 ACM.+ACI-

column33: +ACI-This study raises the question of what the emotional significance of the digital patterns has and attempts to provide an answer to such a question. The purpose of this study is to propose a direction to effectively support the fa+//0Aw//9AKc-ade designs of buildings by understanding the emotive design characteristics of the patterns. This study explains the design patterns on fa+//0Aw//9AKc-ade designs. There are five types of digital patterns which include applied patterns
column37: and tiled patterns. Among those patterns
column38: perforated patterns are focused in further detail. This study deals with identifying emotional effects of perforated design patterns. The emotional word 'asymmetrical' and 'irregular' shows the high average of the emotional value. In the bipolar adjectives
column39: the high emotional value is 'irregular+AC0-regular' and 'asymmetrical+AC0-symmetrical'. Therefore
column40: the final design characteristics of the perforated patterns are 'regularity' and 'symmetry'. This means to be able to use the perforated patterns in order to be perceived a building fa+//0Aw//9AKc-ade design as the regular and symmetrical emotional effect. In this paper
column41: it is worth analyzing design characteristics of a building fa+//0Aw//9AKc-ade by the support of the digital technologies and discussing the utilization of design characteristics derived. This study has contributed to the process and method of deriving the analysis results. +//0Awv/9AKk- 2015 All rights reserved and published by The Association for Computer+AC0-Aided Architectural Design Research in Asia (CAADRIA)

column48: +ACI-Usability is a software system quality attribute. There are usability issues that have an impact not only on the user interface but also on the core functionality of applications. In this paper
column49: three web applications were developed to discover patterns for implementing two usability functionalities with an impact on core functionality: Abort Operation and Progress Feedback. We applied an inductive process in order to identify reusable elements to implement the selected functionalities. For communication purposes
column50: these elements are specified as design and programming patterns (PHP
column51: VB.NET and Java). Another two web applications were developed in order to evaluate the patterns. The evaluation explores several issues such as ease of pattern understanding and ease of pattern use
column52: as well as the final result of the applications. We found that it is feasible to reuse the identified solutions specified as patterns. The results also show that usability functionalities have features
column53: like the level of coupling with the application or the complexity of each component of the solution
column54: that simplify or complicate their implementation. In this case
column55: the Abort Operation functionality turned out to be more feasible to implement than the Progress Feedback functionality.+ACI-

column10: ACM International Conference Proceeding Series
column32: +ACI-Feature interactions have been an intensive field of research for more than a decade. Recently
column33: it gained much attention in the context of software product lines (SPLs)
column34: a methodology that takes features explicitly into account to distinguish between similar yet different programs. In its very essence
column35: feature interactions occur whenever the presence of two or more features leads to a considerable (and maybe unwanted) change of the behavior of the underlying program. Amongst others
column36: feature interactions may occur on source code level
column38: in form of additional code that is needed due to interacting features. In this paper
column39: we focus on such structural interactions. Particularly
column40: we investigate structural feature interaction patterns
column42: patterns that are related to structural feature interactions
column43: and vice versa. To this end
column44: we propose an approach to detect design patterns in feature+AC0-oriented SPLs. We show that such design patterns exist on feature level and these patterns involve feature interactions. Based on our results
column45: we reason about feature interactions in the presence of design patterns. Particularly
column46: we show when feature interactions occur and that they are beneficial
column48: to achieve a higher degree of abstraction. Furthermore
column49: we propose an initial guideline when certain design patterns are applicable. +//0Awv/9AKk- 2014 ACM.+ACI-

column52: +ACI-The process of understanding and reusing software is often time+AC0-consuming
column53: especially in legacy code and open+AC0-source libraries. While some core code of open+AC0-source libraries may be well+AC0-documented
column54: it is frequently the case that open+AC0-source libraries lack informative API documentation and reliable design information. As a result
column55: the source code itself is often the sole reliable source of information for program understanding activities. In this article
column56: we propose a reverse+AC0-engineering approach that can provide assistance during the process of understanding software through the automatic recovery of hidden design patterns in software libraries. Specifically
column57: we use ontology formalism to represent the conceptual knowledge of the source code and semantic rules to capture the structures and behaviors of the design patterns in the libraries. Several software libraries were examined with this approach and the evaluation results show that effective and flexible detection of design patterns can be achieved without using hard+AC0-coded heuristics. +//0Awv/9AKk- 2013 Springer+AC0-Verlag Berlin Heidelberg.+ACI-

column6: Design pattern decay: The case for class grime
column8: International Symposium on Empirical Software Engineering and Measurement
column34: a form of design pattern decay
column35: wherein classes of the pattern realization have extraneous attributes or methods
column36: which obfuscate the intended design of a pattern. Goal: To expand the taxonomy of class grime using properties of class cohesion. Using this expanded taxonomy we explore the effect that forms of class grime have on pattern realization understandability. Method: A pilot study utilizing a formal experiment to explore the effects of class grime on design pattern understandability. The experiments used simulated injection of 8 types of class grime into design pattern realizations randomly selected from 16 design pattern types from a set of 6541 realizations from 520 distinct software systems. Results: We found that for each of the 8 identified class grime forms
column37: understandability was negatively affected. Conclusion: This work serves as early communication of research for the validation of the extended taxonomy as well as the method of grime injection used in the experiment. +//0Awv/9AKk- 2014 ACM.+ACI-

column8: Using metric+AC0-based filtering to improve design pattern detection approaches
column10: Innovations in Systems and Software Engineering
column38: +ACI-Design patterns represent high+AC0-level recurring abstractions that reflect the know+AC0-how of experts. Their detection is a key task in the context of software engineering+ADs- it is very useful in program comprehension
column39: design recovery and also for re+AC0-documenting object+AC0-oriented systems. Despite their usefulness
column40: current design pattern detection approaches have a high time complexity that hinders their application. This complexity is further aggravated with the absence of guiding principles in determining which pattern to look for first among the various patterns. To overcome this practical limit
column41: we propose to optimize any pattern detection approach by foregoing it by a filtering phase that detects possible existence of patterns and that orders the candidate patterns in terms of their degree of resemblance to the analyzed design fragments. The herein proposed filtering approach exploits semantic and structural design metrics to look for the semantic and structural symptoms of design pattern instances. Its performance is experimentally demonstrated through our design pattern detection method MAPeD (Multi+AC0-phase Approach for Pattern Discovery) applied on the open source system JUnit. +//0Awv/9AKk- 2014

column36: +ACI-The centrality of Uniform Resource Identifiers (URI) as names in Linked Data initiatives has led to the development of guidelines and best practices by World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) and other experts groups on how to design +ACIAIg-good+ACIAIg- URIs in general and for the government domain in particular. However
column37: these URI design guidelines have had limited pragmatic value for several reasons including the underspecified nature of the rules
column38: weak elaboration on nature of problems addressed and consequences of prescribed design decisions. With no conceptual or rigorous underpinning for existing design rules
column39: checking for internal consistency or coverage when developing URI strategies is difficult. We tackle these problems in this paper by: 1) consolidating existing URI design rules
column40: 2) distilling core URI design aspects or facets from these rules and 3) abstracting the rules into a set of consistent URI Design Patterns specifications. This process resulted in 8 Design Patterns from an initial set of 37 URI design rules. Following this
column41: we show how the design patterns could be employed in developing a URI strategy to support the realization of a Linked Spatial Data Infrastructure. We conclude with an evaluation of the URI design patterns and implications of our work. +//0Awv/9AKk- 2014 IEEE.+ACI-

column36: +ACI-Design patterns are a proven way to build flexible software architectures. But the selection of an appropriate design pattern is a difficult task in practice

column39: a new design pattern advisement ontology will be defined. We have also developed a tool that supports the proposed ontology and question+AC0-based advisement (OQBA) approach. column8: Ontology alignment design patterns
column10: Knowledge and Information Systems
column42: +ACI-Interoperability between heterogeneous ontological descriptions can be performed through ontology mediation techniques. At the heart of ontology mediation lies the alignment: a specification of correspondences between ontology entities. Ontology matching can bring some automation but are limited to finding simple correspondences. Design patterns have proven themselves useful to capture experience in design problems. In this article
column43: we introduce ontology alignment patterns as reusable templates of recurring correspondences. Based on a detailed analysis of frequent ontology mismatches
column44: we develop a library of common patterns. Ontology alignment patterns can be used to refine correspondences
column45: either by the alignment designer or via pattern detection algorithms. We distinguish three levels of abstraction for ontology alignment representation
column47: to concrete correspondences between two ontologies
column48: to ontology alignment patterns at the third level. We express patterns using an ontology alignment representation language
column49: making them ready to use in practical mediation tasks. We extract mismatches from vocabularies associated with data sets published as linked open data
column50: and we evaluate the ability of correspondence patterns to provide proper alignments for these mismatches. Finally
column51: we describe an application of ontology alignment patterns for an ontology transformation service. +//0Awv/9AKk- 2013 Springer+AC0-Verlag London.+ACI-

column6: Reliable yet flexible software through formal model transformation (rule definition)
column8: Knowledge and Information Systems
column33: +ACI-The results of literature review show that the need for both reliability and flexibility is increasingly becoming important among the various classes of software applications. Developing reliable yet flexible software is a hard problem. Although modeling methods enjoy a lot of advantages
column34: the use of just one of them
column36: may not guarantee the development of reliable and flexible software. Formal modeling methods ensure reliability. However
column37: lack of knowledge and high cost practically force developers to use semi+AC0-formal methods instead. Semi+AC0-formal (visual) modeling methods
column38: which are widely used in practical large+AC0-scale software development
column39: are not good enough for reliable software development. This paper proposes a new practical approach to the development of reliable yet flexible software. In the proposed approach
column40: formal (Object+AC0-Z) and semi+AC0-formal (UML) models are transformed into each other using a set of bidirectional formal rules. Formal modeling and refinement ensure the reliability of software. Visual models facilitate the interactions among stakeholders who are not familiar enough with the complex mathematical concepts of formal methods. Visual models help detect the unexpected behavior and inconsistencies of software. Applying design patterns to visual models improves the flexibility of software. The transformation of formal and visual models into each other through the iterative and evolutionary process
column42: helps develop the software applications that need to be highly reliable yet flexible. The feasibility of the proposed approach is evaluated using the multi+AC0-lift case study. +//0Awv/9AKk- 2013 Springer+AC0-Verlag London.+ACI-

column21: India+ADs- Indraprastha Institute of Information Technology
column37: +ACI-The way an application is designed and certain patterns thereof
column38: play a significant role and might have a positive or a negative effect on the performance of the application. Some design patterns that have a negative effect on performance
column40: may become important when evaluating migrating the application to the Cloud. Although there has been work done in the past related to defining performance antipatterns
column41: there has been none that highlights the importance and effects of these performance antipatterns when an application is migrated to Cloud. In this work we present an approach to automatically detect important performance antipatterns in an application
column42: by leveraging static code analysis and information about prospective deployment of the application components on the Cloud. We also experimentally show that these antipatterns may become prominent and pull down the application's performance if the application is migrated to the Cloud. Our results show that the performance of the parts of the application with such antipatterns suffer significantly and hence
column43: the detection of these antipatterns has an overarching significance in the domain of software development for the Cloud. The approach we present here has also been implemented in a prototype cloud migration assessment tool. +//0Awv/9AKk- 2014 IEEE.+ACI-

column49: +ACI-Software design patterns are abstract descriptions of best practice solutions for recurring design problems. The information about which design pattern is implemented where in a software design is very helpful and important for software maintenance and evolution. This information is usually lost due to poor
column51: which raises the importance of automatic recognition techniques. However
column52: their vague and abstract nature allows them to be implemented in various ways
column53: which gives them resistance to be automatically and accurately recognized. This paper presents the first recognition approach to be solely based on machine learning methods. We build a training dataset by using several existing recognition tools and we use feature selection methods to select the input feature vectors. Artificial neural networks are then trained to perform the whole recognition process. Our approach is evaluated by conducting an experiment to recognize six design patterns in an open source application. +//0Awv/9AKk- 2013 IEEE.+ACI-

column58: +ACI-New technologies are entering medical practice at an astounding pace. However
column59: these technologies often cause to doctors learn and use difficulties. Then
column60: doctors require assistance of a biomedical engineer. This is currently happening in a local hospital that has new technology to analyze biomechanical protocols in patients. Protocols are used to measure performances and identify changes in human body movements and muscles. Doctors are neither familiar with the concepts nor tools used
column61: so biomedical engineers carry out descriptions of protocols rather than doctors. In this paper
column62: we present the design of a domain+AC0-specific language that enables doctors to specify biomechanical protocols by addressing learning barriers (using design patterns). We also make doctors' descriptions compatible with the existing tools
column63: and we also support legacy biomedical descriptions (combining meta+AC0-modeling and model transformations). +//0Awv/9AKk- 2013 IEEE.+ACI-

column42: +ACI-Detecting design pattern instances from source codes can assist the understanding of the systems. This paper presents an approach to the detection of design patterns based on graph isomorphism. We introduce two kinds of graphs
column43: among which one represents the system design and the other describes the design patterns to be recovered. In order to detect instances of design patterns
column44: we first identify in system graph all the candidate classes that correspond to the pattern classes. Afterwards we select some of candidate classes to form the sub+AC0-graphs of system graph
column45: which are then checked isomorphic to the pattern graph or not. Those isomorphic sub+AC0-graphs are regarded to be corresponding to instances of the design patterns. The detection of decorator pattern is given as the example to show the effectiveness of the approach. +//0Awv/9AKk- 2013 IEEE.+ACI-

column52: +ACI-Software design patterns describe recurring design problems and provide the essence of best practice solutions. It is useful and important
column54: to know which design pattern is implemented where in a software design. However
column55: this information is often lost due to poor or absent documentation
column56: and so accurate recognition tools are required. The problem is that design patterns
column57: given their abstract and vague nature
column58: have a level of resistance to be automatically and accurately recognized. Although this vagueness or fuzziness can be captured and modelled by the fuzzy inference system
column59: it has not yet been applied to solve this problem. This paper fills this gap by proposing an approach for design pattern recognition based on Adaptive Neuro Fuzzy Inference System. Our approach consists of two phases: space reduction phase and design pattern recognition phase. Both phases are implemented by ANFIS. We evaluate the approach by an experiment conducted to recognize six design patterns in an open source application. The results show that the approach is viable and promising. +//0Awv/9AKk- 2013 IEEE.+ACI-

column37: We have explored the use of a generic ontology component to separate and encapsulate the design pattern logic of the GoF creational design patterns. We used a unique generic ontology as a runtime component in the creational patterns and then analyzed and compared the implementations with that of traditional GoF creational patterns. We concluded after experimental analysis that ontology driven solutions to creational design patterns not only mitigate the drawbacks identified in the creational patterns but also make the patterns a plug and play component whereby the desired objects can be created on the fly. +//0Awv/9AKk- 2013 ACM.

column37: +ACI-SOA brought significant progress in information systems development
column38: but the full exploitation of its advantages is sometimes hindered by specific problems. One of them is concerned with paradigm of Model Driven Development (MDD)
column39: where it is necessary to control correctness of the whole design within many models on different levels of abstraction. This is the place
column40: where we would like to contribute. We propose a new approach to application of SOA design patterns in the development process. Patterns are transformed into a machine acceptable form using category theory and attributed graphs. This form is language independent
column41: leads up to automated detection of pattern or antipattern in the description/model of SOA based system and in the future can facilitate also correctness checking. +//0Awv/9AKk- 2013 IEEE.+ACI-

column28: +ACI-Middleware systems are widely recognized as complex software systems. The origin of this complexity is mainly related to the need of providing distribution transparencies (e.g.
column34: concurrency control) to distributed application developers. This complexity suggests the use of formal methods that can help in both understanding of the middleware's behavior and checking of desired middleware properties. Due to the aforementioned complexity
column35: the formalization itself is also not a trivial task. In this context
column36: this paper presents an approach to formalize middleware systems centered on the formalization and composition of middleware design patterns. In order to illustrate the proposed approach
column37: we formalize and check properties of an object oriented middleware. +//0Awv/9AKk- 2013 IEEE.+ACI-

column6: Relaxing queries to detect variants of design patterns
column8: +ACI-2013 Federated Conference on Computer Science and Information Systems
column40: +ACI-Design patterns codify general solutions to frequently encountered design problems. They also facilitate writing robust and readable code. Their usage happens to be particularly profitable if the documentation of the resulting system is lost
column41: inaccurate or out of date. In reverse engineering
column42: detection of instances of design patterns is extremely helpful as it aids grasping high level design ideas. However
column43: the actual instances of design patterns can diverge from their canonical textbook templates. Useful pattern detection tools should thus be able to identify not only orthodox implementations but also their disparate variants. In this paper
column44: we present a method to generate queries to detect canonical instances of design patters. We formulate these queries so that they are language+AC0-agnostic. They precisely reflect the intents of the canonical implementations of design patterns. However
column45: they abstract from any peculiarities of programming languages. Next
column46: we show a systematic technique to relax these queries so that they also cover variant implementations of patterns. We discuss our proof+AC0-of+AC0-concept implementation of this approach in our prototype tool D+AC0-CUBED. Finally
column47: we report the results of an experimental comparison of D+AC0-CUBED and state+AC0-of+AC0-the+AC0-art detectors. +//0Awv/9AKk- 2013 Polish Information Processing Society.+ACI-

column54: +ACI-The objective of this paper is to propose a methodology for strictly separating fault detection and fault handling methods from control code in discrete manufacturing systems. In order to enable the separation
column55: two different design patterns are elaborated. Based on an analysis of typical faults in manufacturing systems
column56: a library of reusable function blocks for fault detection
column58: and also fault recovery is developed. These function blocks are implemented according to the international standard IEC 61499 and are applied within the design patterns. The design patterns are evaluated with the sequential control of an injection molding machine. It is shown
column59: that the design patterns simplify the engineering and the separation of the fault detection and fault handling from control code significantly
column60: since they provide clear design rules. Applying the proposed design patterns reduces the complexity of industrial control applications drastically. Furthermore
column61: the function block library provides reusable and proven fault detection and fault handling methods. +//0Awv/9AKk- 2013 IEEE.+ACI-

column49: we propose a new approach to improve the results of the heuristics evaluation performed by novice evaluators combining the classical usability reports with the interaction pattern design in concrete types of usability problems. Normally
column50: usability reports generated by experts or by any automatic tool are limited to a list of problems detected with qualitative and quantitative data plus graphics or simple suggestions for solving detected problems. Sometimes these suggestions are not sufficient to fix the detected problem
column51: as the designer is not able to capture or reproduce the problem. Our proposal will provide support to designers
column52: trying to unify the recommendations offered by evaluators introducing the concept of design patterns in the report. In this manner
column53: the final report could be enriched with one design pattern for some of the detected usability problems
column54: thus enabling a better understanding of the detected issue by designers. +//0Awv/9AKk- 2013 ACM.+ACI-

column45: +ACI-Code review is a very important means to ensure the quality of code in practice. It has been widely used in industry since it was proposed. Nowadays code review is still mainly done by manual work in industry. However
column46: increasing scale of the software challenges manual reviewing. So automating the code review process is highly desired. Design patterns are a set of summaries of code design experiences that are widely used repeatedly
column47: and well classified. Programmers need to correctly implement code based on design patterns. To ensure that the code is implemented as expected
column48: this paper proposes an approach to automatically review code in the view of specified design patterns. Firstly
column49: we identify the design patterns that are specified in the design models. Second
column50: we construct a set of review rules by extracting design constraints from identified design patterns. Last
column51: the code is checked against the generated review rules
column52: and inconsistencies are reported as result. A supporting tool was developed
column53: and two experiments were conducted to demonstrate the applicability of our approach. +//0Awv/9AKk- 2013 IEEE.+ACI-

column41: +ACI-Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition (SCADA) systems are widely used in automated manufacturing and in all areas of our nation's infrastructure. Current research on SCADA security focuses on the primary SCADA components and targets network centric attacks. Security risks via attacks against the peripheral devices such as the Programmable Logic Controllers (PLCs) have not been sufficiently addressed. Since PLCs dictate the functionality of the processes it is crucial that they function correctly and securely. In this paper we study the problem of providing safety and security for ladder logic code. We argue that general purpose safety and security methods are insufficient for PLCs due to the specific context and the unique processing logic of ladder logic applications. We present a PLC Security Framework (PLC+AC0-SF) that is compatible with the current PLC compilers
column42: detects and classifies incorrect and unsafe ladder logic code. After the classification of the vulnerabilities
column43: PLC+AC0-SF recommends appropriate design+AC0-patterns to eliminate the problems. +//0Awv/9AKk- 2013 IEEE.+ACI-

column34: +ACI-Software design patterns are solutions to recurring problems. These solutions have been widely accepted and adopted by the software practitioners. Design Patterns were initially described informally through the use of textual descriptions or some object oriented graphical notations. However
column35: informal descriptions of design patterns give rise to ambiguity and incorrect usage of the design pattern. Many design pattern specification languages have been proposed to address the shortcomings of informal descriptions. These design pattern formalization techniques have been developed for different intentions including verification of design patterns and detection of design patterns in source code. In this paper we provide a set of evaluation criteria to evaluate and compare the various design pattern specification languages in order to aid practitioners and researchers to select the appropriate language for their use. +//0Awv/9AKk- 2013 IEEE.+ACI-

column48: Traffic classification is a core problem underlying efficient implementation of network services. In this work we draw from our experience in classifier design for commercial systems to address this problem in SDN and OpenFlow. We identify methods from other fields of computer science and show research directions that can be applied for efficient design of packet classifiers. Proposed abstractions and design patterns can significantly reduce requirements on network elements and enable deployment of functionality that would be infeasible in a traditional way. +//0Awv/9AKk- 2013 ACM.

column59: such systems need security and dependability (S+ACY-D) constraints. Usually S+ACY-D design patterns shape S+ACY-D mechanisms. column43: +ACI-Design patterns are used in software development to provide reusable and documented solutions to common design problems. Although many studies have explored various aspects of design patterns
column44: no research summarizing the state of research related to design patterns existed up to now. This paper presents the results of a mapping study of about 120 primary studies
column45: to provide an overview of the research efforts on Gang of Four (GoF) design patterns. The research questions of this study deal with (a) if design pattern research can be further categorized in research subtopics
column46: (b) which of the above subtopics are the most active ones and (c) what is the reported effect of GoF patterns on software quality attributes. The results suggest that design pattern research can be further categorized to research on GoF patterns formalization
column47: detection and application and on the effect of GoF patterns on software quality attributes. Concerning the intensity of research activity of the abovementioned subtopics
column48: research on pattern detection and on the effect of GoF patterns on software quality attributes appear to be the most active ones. Finally
column49: the reported research to date on the effect of GoF patterns on software quality attributes are controversial+ADs- because some studies identify one pattern's effect as beneficial whereas others report the same pattern's effect as harmful. +//0Awv/9AKk- 2013 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.+ACI-

column48: +ACI-Design patterns are well+AC0-known design solutions that are reported to produce substantial benefits with respect to software quality. However

column50: where developers can identify reusable components and researchers can find a mined data set. Currently
column51: 141 open source projects have been considered and more than 4500 pattern instances have been found and recorded in the database of the repository. column34: +ACI-Design patterns represent the best practices used by experienced java developers. Design patterns abstract reusable object+AC0-oriented software designs which are solutions to general problems that software developers faced during software development. Each pattern solves design problems that occur in every day development. The detection of design patterns during the process of software reverse engineering can provide a better understanding of the software system. The most recent approaches in design pattern detection rely on the abstract syntax tree representation of the source code for fact extraction. This paper proposes a new way to detect design pattern in Java applications by analyzing the java source code. This paper discussed about the relations both between classes and objects and established the derivative design pattern about model property. Using the roles
column35: responsibilities and collaboration information of each design pattern define static definitions. The static definitions are used to find candidate instances during the static analysis by using BCEL. After the static analysis the found candidate instances are validated by using the dynamic behavior of design patterns. We instrument the Java byte code of the application we are analyzing with additional code fragments and extract method traces from the running application. These method traces represent the dynamic facts of an application. The several restrictions are presented to define design patterns dynamically. Four common patterns of original GoF design patterns are tested and the results are analyzed which give better results in detecting design patterns comparing with other tools. In addition a Java source code static checking tool
column37: is implemented. Finally several java applications source codes were analyzed by using the plug+AC0-in
column38: and verified the feasibility of the approach. +//0Awv/9AKk- 2013 IEEE.+ACI-

column50: +ACI-Design patterns capitalize the knowledge of expert designers and offer reuse that provides for higher design quality and overall faster development. To attain these advantages
column53: overcome the difficulties in understanding design patterns and determining those appropriate for his/her particular application. On the other hand
column54: one way to benefit from design patterns is to assist inexperienced designers in pattern detection during the design elaboration. Such detection should tolerate variations between the design and the pattern since the exact instantiation of a pattern is infrequent in a design. However
column55: not all variations of a pattern are tolerated. In particular
column56: some structural variations may result in non+AC0-optimal instantiations where the requirements are respected but the structure is different+ADs- such variations are called spoiled patterns and should also be detected and transformed into acceptable pattern instantiations. This paper first presents an improvement of our design/spoiled pattern detection approach
column57: named MAPeD (Multi+AC0-phase Approach for Pattern Discovery). The latter uses an XML information retrieval technique to identify design/spoiled pattern occurrences in a design using
column61: dynamic information. This multi+AC0-phase detection approach tolerates structural differences between the examined design and the identified design pattern. Furthermore
column62: thanks to the matching information it collects
column63: our identification technique can offer assistance for the improvement of a design. In its second contribution
column64: this paper evaluates MAPeD by comparing its recall and precision rates for five open source systems: JHotDraw
column68: QuickUML. The latter were used by other approaches in experimental evaluations. column56: +ACI-This paper proposes a software architecture based on LabVIEW for controlling discrete event systems. The proposed architecture is an adaptation of the producer+AC0-consumer design pattern. This work uses the control software of a multifunctional robotic end+AC0-effector as a test+AC0-bed for analyzing the applicability of the software architecture and its limitations and advantages. This case study demonstrates the effectiveness of the architecture for dealing with the integration of multiple functionalities in the control system. For this case study
column57: the validation of the architecture is performed using two verification techniques: (1) a formal verification using timed automata and the UPPAAL model checker and (2) the CoFI (Conformance and Fault Injection) method for defining the set of test cases to check the software product. column42: +ACI-Architectural tactics are important building blocks of software architecture. Tactics come in many shapes and sizes
column43: describe solutions for addressing specific quality concerns
column44: and are prevalent across high+AC0-performance fault+AC0-tolerant systems. Once a decision is made to utilize a tactic
column45: the developer must generate a concrete plan for realizing the tactic in the design and code. Unfortunately
column46: the variability points found in individual tactics can make this a challenging task. To address this knowledge gap
column47: we conducted a study to investigate how design patterns were used to implement various tactics. Data mining techniques were used to identify potential pattern instances within tactic implementations. Our manual analysis of the retrieved data identified a distinct set of variability points for each tactic
column48: as well as corresponding design patterns used to address them. From these observations we construct tactic+AC0-level decision trees depicting variability points of a tactic and generate a reference model which provides implementation guidance. +//0Awv/9AKk- 2012 ACM.+ACI-

column41: +ACI-Identifying design patterns from source code is one of the most promising methods for improving software maintainability

column43: an approach that combines static and dynamic analysis on detecting design patterns from java source code is presented. Static structure analysis of identifying pattern instances is illustrated. Especially

column6: Understanding design patterns +AC0- What is the problem?
column8: Software +AC0- Practice and Experience
column34: +ACI-Design patterns codify proven solutions to recurring design problems. Their proper use within a development context requires that: (i) we understand them+ADs- (ii) we ascertain their applicability or relevance to the design problem at hand+ADs- and (iii) we apply them faithfully to the problem at hand. We argue that an explicit representation of the design problem solved by a design pattern is key to supporting the three tasks in an integrated fashion. We propose a model+AC0-driven representation of design patterns consisting of triples +ADw- MP
column36: T +AD4- where MP is a model of the problem solved by the pattern
column37: MS is a model of the solution proposed by the pattern
column38: and T is a model transformation of an instance of the problem into an instance of the solution. Given an object+AC0-oriented design model
column39: we look for model fragments that match MP (call them instances of MP)
column41: we apply the transformation T yielding an instance of MS. Easier said than done. Experimentation with an Eclipse Modeling Framework+AC0-based implementation of our approach applied to a number of open+AC0-source software application's raised fundamental questions about: (i) the nature of design patterns in general
column42: and the ones that lend themselves to our approach
column43: and (ii) our understanding and codification of seemingly simple design patterns. In this paper
column44: we present the principles behind our approach
column45: report on the results of applying the approach to the Gang of Four (GoF) design patterns
column46: and discuss the representability of design problems solved by these patterns. Copyright +//0Awv/9AKk- 2011 John Wiley +ACY- Sons

column6: ENASE 2012 +AC0- Proceedings of the 7th International Conference on Evaluation of Novel Approaches to Software Engineering
column22: AGH University of Science and Technology
column26: +ACI-The work concerns gathering requirements and their formal verification using deductive approach. This approach is based on the semantic tableaux reasoning method and temporal logic. The semantic tableaux method is quite intuitive and has some advantages over traditional deduction strategies. System requirements are gathered using some UML diagrams. Requirements engineering based on formal analysis and verification might play an essential role in producing the correct software since this approach increases reliability and trust in software. Deductive inference is always the most natural for human beings and is used intuitively in everyday life. A use case
column27: its scenario and its activity diagram may be linked to each other during the process of gathering requirements. When activities and actions are identified in the use case scenario then their workflows are modeled using the activity diagram. Organizing the activity diagram workflows into design patterns enables the automation of the process of generating logical specifications. The automation of this process is crucial and constitutes a challenge in the whole deductive approach. Temporal logic properties and formulas may be difficult to specify by inexperienced users and this fact can be a significant obstacle to the practical use of deduction+AC0-based verification tools. The approach presented in this paper attempts to overcome this problem. Automatic transformation of workflow patterns to temporal logic formulas is proposed. These formulas constitute logical specifications of requirements models. The architecture of an automatic and deduction+AC0-based verification system is proposed. Applying this innovative concept results in the reduction of software development costs as some errors might be addressed in the software requirements phase and not in the implementation or testing phases.+ACI-

column58: +ACI-One of the goals of Software Engineering is to reduce
column59: or at least to try to control
column60: the defectiveness of software systems during the development phase. The aim of our study is to analyze the relationship between micro patterns (introduced by Gil and Maman) and faults in a software system. Micro patterns are similar to design patterns
column61: but their characteristic is that they can be identified automatically
column62: and are at a lower level of abstraction with respect to design patterns. Our study aims to show
column63: through empirical studies of open source software systems
column64: which categories of micro patterns are more correlated to faults. Gil and Maman demonstrated
column66: that 75+ACU- of the classes of a software system are covered by micro patterns. In our study we also analyze the relationship between faults and the remaining 25+ACU- of classes that do not match with any micro pattern. We found that these classes are more likely to be fault+AC0-prone than the others. We also studied the correlation among all the micro patterns of the catalog
column67: in order to verify the existence of relationships between them. +//0Awv/9AKk- 2012 IEEE.+ACI-

column54: +ACI-Context: The automated identification of code fragments characterized by common design flaws (or +ACIAIg-code smells+ACIAIg-) that can be handled through refactoring
column56: especially in large code bases where multiple developers are engaged without a detailed view on the whole system. Automated refactoring to design patterns enables significant contributions to design quality even from developers with little experience on the use of the required patterns. Objective: This work targets the automated identification of refactoring opportunities to the Strategy design pattern and the elimination through polymorphism of respective +ACIAIg-code smells+ACIAIg- that are related to extensive use of complex conditional statements. Method: An algorithm is introduced for the automated identification of refactoring opportunities to the Strategy design pattern. Suggested refactorings comprise conditional statements that are characterized by analogies to the Strategy design pattern
column57: in terms of the purpose and selection mode of strategies. Moreover
column58: this work specifies the procedure for refactoring to Strategy the identified conditional statements. For special cases of these statements
column59: a technique is proposed for total replacement of conditional logic with method calls of appropriate concrete Strategy instances. The identification algorithm and the refactoring procedure are implemented and integrated in the JDeodorant Eclipse plug+AC0-in. The method is evaluated on a set of Java projects
column60: in terms of quality of the suggested refactorings and run+AC0-time efficiency. The relevance of the identified refactoring opportunities is verified by expert software engineers. Results: The identification algorithm recalled
column61: from the projects used during evaluation
column62: many of the refactoring candidates that were identified by the expert software engineers. Its execution time on projects of varying size confirmed the run+AC0-time efficiency of this method. Conclusion: The proposed method for automated refactoring to Strategy contributes to simplification of conditional statements. Moreover
column63: it enhances system extensibility through the Strategy design pattern. +//0Awv/9AKk- 2012 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.+ACI-

column37: +ACI-This paper presents architectural performance requirements for a framework dedicated to Augmented Reality (AR) applications. This work has been made as a starting point to evaluation of a framework named ARCS (Augmented Reality Component Systems) allowing rapid+AC0-prototyping
column39: debugging and monitoring of AR applications. The article first introduces the need of such a dedicated framework and the importance of distribution for AR. It also identifies main features that should be offered by an AR framework and key performance criteria to be satisfied. These are partially inspired by the SPE (Software Performance Engineering) distributed architecture evaluation approach. These criteria are application specific. Thus
column40: we first classify different distributed AR applications in scenarios and extract relevant criteria for each. We also provide a custom assessment protocol inspired by SPE evaluation methodology and based on previously identified criteria. This assessment is application independent as it is based on generic design patterns and most likely scenarios of distribution. Keeping in mind identified criteria and handling existing framework's constraints
column41: a reliable generic AR framework should satisfy all criteria for each application class. Assessment protocol results for each criterion are compared to the typical features and performance that should be offered by an AR system. +//0Awv/9AKk- 2012 IEEE.+ACI-

column8: Selecting spatiotemporal patterns for development of parallel applications
column10: IEEE Transactions on Parallel and Distributed Systems
column28: Computer Science and Artificial Intelligence Laboratory
column35: Computer Science and Artificial Intelligence Laboratory
column42: Computer Science and Artificial Intelligence Laboratory
column48: +ACI-Design patterns for parallel computing attempt to make the field accessible to nonexperts by generalizing the common techniques experts use to develop parallel software. Existing parallel patterns have tremendous descriptive power
column49: but it is often unclear to nonexperts how to choose a pattern based on the specific performance goals of a given application. This paper addresses the need for a pattern selection methodology by presenting four patterns and an accompanying decision framework for choosing from these patterns given an application's throughput and latency goals. The patterns are based on recognizing that one can partition an application's data or instructions and that these partitionings can be done in time or space
column50: hence we refer to them as spatiotemporal partitioning strategies. This paper introduces a taxonomy that describes each of the resulting four partitioning strategies and presents a three+AC0-step methodology for selecting one or more given a throughput and latency goal. Several case studies are presented to illustrate the use of this methodology. These case studies cover several simple examples as well as more complicated applications including a radar processing application and an H.264 video encoder. +//0Awv/9AKk- 2012 IEEE.+ACI-

column45: +ACI-Domain+AC0-Specific Modeling Languages (DSMLs) have received recent interest due to their conciseness and rich expressiveness for modeling a specific domain. However
column46: DSML adoption has several challenges because development of a new DSML requires both domain knowledge and language development expertise (e.g.
column47: defining abstract/concrete syntax and specifying semantics). Abstract syntax is generally defined in the form of a metamodel
column48: with semantics associated to the metamodel. Thus
column49: designing a metamodel is a core DSML development activity. Furthermore
column50: DSMLs are often developed incrementally by iterating across complex language development tasks. An iterative and incremental approach is often preferred because the approach encourages end+AC0-user involvement to assist with verifying the DSML correctness and feedback on new requirements. However
column51: if there is no tool support
column52: iterative and incremental DSML development can be mundane and error+AC0-prone work. To resolve issues related to DSML development
column53: we introduce a new approach to create DSMLs from a set of domain model examples provided by an end+AC0-user. The approach focuses on (1) the identification of concrete syntax
column54: (2) inducing abstract syntax in the form of a metamodel
column55: and (3) inferring static semantics from a set of domain model examples. In order to generate a DSML from user+AC0-supplied examples
column56: our approach uses graph theory and metamodel design patterns. +//0Awv/9AKk- 2012 IEEE.+ACI-

column36: +ACI-Documented design decisions simplify the evolution of software systems. However
column37: currently design decisions are often either badly documented or are not documented at all. Relations between requirements
column40: and architecture alternatives are not preserved. As a consequence it is hard to identify deprecated design solutions when requirements change In this position paper
column41: we present an approach to document software architecture design decisions
column42: together with related requirements and related architectural elements
column43: through the goal+AC0-driven elicitation of those requirements needed to make a design decision. Therefore
column44: we propose a process model and supporting meta+AC0-models
column45: including a meta+AC0-model for a pattern catalogue. The speciality of this pattern catalogue is the inclusion of questions to drive requirements engineering to validate pattern selections
column46: and to guide choosing the most appropriate pattern variant. The paper concludes with a discussion on the assumptions of the approach and possible approaches to empirical validation. Copyright +//0Awv/9AKk- 2012 ACM.+ACI-

column38: +ACI-Designing a high quality model transformation is critical
column39: because it is the pivotal mechanism in many mission applications for evolving the intellectual design described by models. This paper proposes solution ideas to assist modelers in developing high quality transformation models. We propose to initiate a design pattern movement in the context of model transformation. The resulting catalog of patterns shall satisfy quality attributes identified beforehand. Verification and validation of these patterns allow us to assess whether the cataloged design patterns are sound and complete with respect to the quality criteria. This will lead to techniques and tools that can detect bad designs and propose alternatives based on well+AC0-thought design patterns during the development or maintenance of model transformation. +//0Awv/9AKk- 2012 IEEE.+ACI-

column6: Value+AC0-sensitive design patterns for pervasive health care
column8: +ACI-2012 IEEE International Conference on Pervasive Computing and Communications Workshops
column35: +ACI-Pervasive computing technologies offer solutions to many of the problems people face in aging. In doing so
column36: they have the potential to support certain values such as human welfare. However
column37: these solutions also have the potential to diminish human values such as trust
column38: privacy and autonomy. Many of such value issues are recurrent
column39: general problems that play out in specific application contexts. By accounting for values during the design of technology
column40: designers would be in a better position to create technology that supports rather than hinders the values of its stakeholders. Yet
column41: there are few methodical approaches to dealing with values in design. Moreover
column42: knowledge on how specific value problems can be tackled is not captured systematically in a reusable way. We propose using Value Sensitive Design to analyze recurrent problems and identify affected stakeholders and their values. We use these analyses as a starting point for generating design patterns
column43: or reusable solutions to recurrent problems
column44: that explicitly include value considerations. We provide an initial set of value+AC0-sensitive design patterns as a proof+AC0-of+AC0-concept. +//0Awv/9AKk- 2012 IEEE.+ACI-

column14: OPAL: Automated form understanding for the deep web
column16: WWW'12 +AC0- Proceedings of the 21st Annual Conference on World Wide Web
column75: +ACI-Forms are our gates to the web. They enable us to access the deep content of web sites. Automatic form understanding unlocks this content for applications ranging from crawlers to meta+AC0-search engines and is essential for improving usability and accessibility of the web. Form understanding has received surprisingly little attention other than as component in specific applications such as crawlers. No comprehensive approach to form understanding exists and previous works disagree even in the definition of the problem. In this paper
column77: the first comprehensive approach to form understanding. We identify form labeling and form interpretation as the two main tasks involved in form understanding. On both problems OPAL pushes the state of the art: For form labeling
column78: it combines signals from the text
column80: and visual rendering of a web page
column81: yielding robust characterisations of common design patterns. In extensive experiments on the ICQ and TEL+AC0-8 benchmarks and a set of 200 modern web forms OPAL outperforms previous approaches by a significant margin. For form interpretation
column82: we introduce a template language to describe frequent form patterns. These two parts of OPAL combined yield form understanding with near perfect accuracy (+AD4- 98+ACU-).+ACI-

column48: +ACI-The ability to quickly identify and rapidly apply effective business practices makes the difference between companies that manage to remain competitive even in crisis situations and companies that suffer from short+AC0-term market changes. column53: and enabling collaboration with colleagues without changing their habits. The paper presents a set of design patterns useful in resolving emerging organizational issues. column6: Exploring the design space of composite visualization
column8: +ACI-IEEE Pacific Visualization Symposium 2012
column28: We propose the notion of composite visualization views (CVVs) as a theoretical model that unifies the existing coordinated multiple views (CMV) paradigm with other strategies for combining visual representations in the same geometrical space. We identify five such strategiescalled CVV design patternsbased on an extensive review of the literature in composite visualization. We go on to show how these design patterns can all be expressed in terms of a design space describing the correlation between two visualizations in terms of spatial mapping as well as the data relationships between items in the visualizations. We also discuss how to use this design space to suggest potential directions for future research. +//0Awv/9AKk- 2012 IEEE.

column45: +ACI-Many activities can be done to support software evolution and reverse engineering of a system. Design pattern detection is one of these activities. It is useful to gain knowledge on the design issues of an existing system
column46: on its architecture and design quality
column47: improving the comprehension of the system and hence its maintainability and evolution. Several tools for design pattern detection have been developed in the literature
column48: but they usually provide different results when analyzing the same systems. Some works have been proposed in the literature to compare these results
column49: but a standard and widely+AC0-accepted benchmark is not yet available. In this work we propose our benchmark web application for design pattern detection
column50: based on a community driven evaluation. +//0Awv/9AKk- 2012 IEEE.+ACI-

column31: +ACI-Automated design pattern detection (DPD) is a challenging reengineering task. The detection quality (precision and recall) of DPD tools has so far been insufficient to make DPD integral part of current IDEs and development practices. In this paper
column32: we present a novel approach and a related tool
column33: DPJF. For all implemented pattern detectors and all projects used for evaluation
column34: DPJF achieves 100+ACU- precision and the best recall of all evaluated tools. Still
column35: its analysis speed competes with the fastest existing tools. The high detection quality is achieved by a well+AC0-balanced combination of structural and behavioural analysis techniques whereas the good performance is achieved by emprically validated simplifications of the individual techniques. Our results lay the basis for routine application of DPD in program comprehension and let DPJF pioneer novel uses of DPD for software quality assesment and improvement. +//0Awv/9AKk- 2012 IEEE.+ACI-

column8: A methodology to assess the impact of design patterns on software quality
column10: Information and Software Technology
column23: Greece+ADs- Information and Communication Systems Engineering Department
column34: Information and Communication Systems Engineering Department
column43: +ACI-Context: Software quality is considered to be one of the most important concerns of software production teams. Additionally
column44: design patterns are documented solutions to common design problems that are expected to enhance software quality. Until now
column45: the results on the effect of design patterns on software quality are controversial. Aims: This study aims to propose a methodology for comparing design patterns to alternative designs with an analytical method. Additionally
column46: the study illustrates the methodology by comparing three design patterns with two alternative solutions
column47: with respect to several quality attributes. Method: The paper introduces a theoretical/ analytical methodology to compare sets of +ACIAIg-canonical+ACIAIg- solutions to design problems. The study is theoretical in the sense that the solutions are disconnected from real systems
column48: even though they stem from concrete problems. The study is analytical in the sense that the solutions are compared based on their possible numbers of classes and on equations representing the values of the various structural quality attributes in function of these numbers of classes. The exploratory designs have been produced by studying the literature
column49: by investigating open+AC0-source projects and by using design patterns. In addition to that
column50: we have created a tool that helps practitioners in choosing the optimal design solution
column51: according to their special needs. Results: The results of our research suggest that the decision of applying a design pattern is usually a trade+AC0-off
column52: because patterns are not universally good or bad. Patterns typically improve certain aspects of software quality
column53: while they might weaken some other. Conclusions: Concluding the proposed methodology is applicable for comparing patterns and alternative designs
column54: and highlights existing threshold that when surpassed the design pattern is getting more or less beneficial than the alternative design. More specifically
column55: the identification of such thresholds can become very useful for decision making during system design and refactoring. +//0Awv/9AKk- 2011 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.+ACI-

column34: +ACI-Replication of software engineering experiments is crucial for dealing with validity threats to experiments in this area. Even though the empirical software engineering community is aware of the importance of replication
column35: the replication rate is still very low. The RESER'11 Joint Replication Project aims to tackle this problem by simultaneously running a series of several replications of the same experiment. In this article
column36: we report the results of the replication run at the Universidad Polit+//0Aw//9AKk-cnica de Madrid. Our results are inconsistent with the original experiment. However
column37: we have identified possible causes for them. We also discuss our experiences (in terms of pros and cons) during the replication. +//0Awv/9AKk- 2012 IEEE.+ACI-

column62: simplified finite element (FE) model of body+AC0-in+AC0-white (BIW) structure focuses on its specific merit to provide early+AC0-stage predictions for detailed FE model of that. This paper exploits a semi+AC0-rigid beam element (SRBE) that consists of a beam element with two semi+AC0-rigid connections at the ends to simulate the flexibility of joint. Guyan reduction method condenses the SRBE as a super element. A special finite element software for structural modeling and analysis of BIW (SMAB) is developed in.NET framework. The Unified Modeling Language is employed to depict the classes and their relationship. The design patterns are identified and applied in the framework design to facilitate communication and system expansion. Microsoft DirectX and GDI implement graphics display of spatial BIW frame and planar thin+AC0-walled cross section. Based on multi+AC0-threaded technology in.NET

column54: +ACI-Model+AC0-driven development (MDD) is a software engineering discipline which suggests that software development should be done at the modelling level and that applications should be generated from models. A key concept of MDD is a model transformation that generates software artifacts
column56: from models. Since models are 'first+AC0-class' citizens in MDD
column57: their verification and validation are important tasks and so are the model transformations. A transformation contract
column59: is a specification of what a particular model transformation must implement and essentially specifies a relation between metamodels and properties that must hold on such a relation. The authors have defined a design pattern that enforces transformation contract correctness over model transformations implementations. This study reports on (i) the proposed design pattern
column60: (ii) the design of the UMLtoEJB model transformation that generates application code
column61: following the Enterprise Java Beans standard
column62: from class diagrams described in the Unified Modelling Language
column63: and (iii) a discussion on how the transformation contracts approach may help different actors
column64: in an MDD software development process with transformation contracts
column65: to identify erroneous situations. +//0Awv/9AKk- 2012 The Institution of Engineering and Technology.+ACI-

column10: Human and program factors affecting the maintenance of programs with deployed design patterns
column25: Hong Kong+ADs- Department of Computer Science and Engineering
column26: Hong Kong University of Science and Technology
column42: Department of Computer Science and Engineering
column43: Hong Kong University of Science and Technology
column52: +ACI-Context: Practitioners may use design patterns to organize program code. Various empirical studies have investigated the effects of pattern deployment and work experience on the effectiveness and efficiency of program maintenance. However
column53: results from these studies are not all consistent. Moreover
column54: these studies have not considered some interesting factors
column55: such as a maintainer's prior exposure to the program under maintenance. Objective: This paper aims at identifying what factors may contribute to the productivity of maintainers in the context of making correct software changes when they work on programs with deployed design patterns. Method: We performed an empirical study involving 118 human subjects with three change tasks on a medium+AC0-sized program to explore the possible effects of a suite of six human and program factors on the productivity of maintainers
column56: measured by the time taken to produce a correctly revised program in a course+AC0-based setting. The factors we studied include the deployment of design patterns and the presence of pattern+AC0-unaware solutions
column57: as well as the maintainer's prior exposure to design patterns
column58: the subject program and the programming language
column59: and prior work experience. Results: Among the factors under examination
column60: we find that the deployment of design patterns
column61: prior exposure to the program and the presence of pattern+AC0-unaware solutions are strongly correlated with the time taken to correctly complete maintenance tasks. We also report some interesting observations from the experiment. Conclusion: A new factor
column64: contributes to the efficient completion of maintenance tasks of programs with deployed design patterns. Moreover

column34: +ACI-Program comprehension requires understanding the structures within the program. Some of these structures are created intentionally and well known (design pattern)
column35: others arise implicitly but are still meaningful
column36: and finally some structures emerge accidentally without any meaning. We build on a previously suggested approach to mine structures in software using Formal Concept Analysis. In contrast to previous work
column37: we found the performance of our tool to be still acceptable for projects of interesting size (+AH4-600 classes). A prominence index for classes based on the formal concepts proved to be helpful for the identification of core structures (high prominence) as well for focusing on specific structures (low prominence). We report about two experiments. In the first the tool guided the experimenter to central structures of JUnit as documented before but unknown by the experimenter. In the second the tool led us to the core structures of our own software.+ACI-

column78: +ACI-This article deals with performance verification of architecture models of real+AC0-time embedded systems. Although real+AC0-time scheduling theory provides numerous analytical methods called feasibility tests for scheduling analysis
column79: their use is a complicated task. In order to assist an architecture model designer in early verification
column81: based on real+AC0-time specific design patterns
column82: enabling an automatic schedulability analysis. This analysis is based on existing feasibility tests
column83: whose selection is deduced from the compliance of the system to a design pattern and other system's properties. Those conformity verifications are integrated into a schedulability tool called Cheddar. We show how to model the relationships between design patterns and feasibility tests and design patterns themselves. Based on these models
column84: we apply a model+AC0-based engineering process to generate
column86: a feasibility test selection tool. The tool is able to detect from an architecture model which are the feasibility tests that the designer can apply. We explain a method for a designer willing to use this approach. We also describe the design patterns defined and the selection algorithm. +//0Awv/9AKk- 2011 ACM.+ACI-

column48: +ACI-One important issue concerning design patterns in reverse engineering is their detection to support program comprehension

column10: Design pattern detection using software metrics and machine learning
column50: and reusability of object+AC0-oriented programs could be improved by automatically detecting well+AC0-known design patterns in programs. Many existing detection techniques are based on static analysis and use strict conditions composed of class structure data. Hence
column51: it is difficult for them to detect design patterns in which the class structures are similar. Moreover
column52: it is difficult for them to deal with diversity in design pattern applications. We propose a design pattern detection technique using metrics and machine learning. Our technique judges candidates for the roles that compose the design patterns by using machine learning and measurements of metrics
column53: and it detects design patterns by analyzing the relations between candidates. It suppresses false negatives and distinguishes patterns in which the class structures are similar. We conducted experiments that showed that our technique was more accurate than two previous techniques.+ACI-

The evolution of in+AC0- creasingly complex computer applications is mandat+AC0- ing the development of technologies and tools that can validate the intended design and can alert developers of potential changes that were not intended by the original designers. Deviations from design patterns oc+AC0- cur as a result of a lack of understanding of intended designs or through evolutionary changes of the soft+AC0- ware+ADs- thus an automated tool is needed to inform de+AC0- velopers when design patterns no longer conform to their original intended design. column22: +ACI-Scope creep can affect the timeliness of the software engineering process. Scope creep often occurs when features are changed or added. Several design patterns provide object oriented constructs whose goal are to mitigate changes in code. Applying these design patterns to formal specifications can help mitigate changes. Structural patterns realize communication between objects
column23: thus identifying how these objects and communications can change. Using a combination of these pattern types

column23: +ACI-This paper introduces an innovative computational design tool used to edit architectural geometry by addressing the problem of irregular vertices. column36: +ACI-Agile project management continues to gain a widening and enthusiastic following. Agile methods can achieve a high level of satisfaction among all project stakeholders (users
column40: and project managers) in terms of productivity
column44: and overall morale. Success with agile requires focus on requirements and design as a continuous discovery process
column45: posing challenges for practitioners of more traditional project management both in terms of method adoption and sustained commitment. Thriving Systems Theory clarifies the appeal of agile project structure and processes
column46: helps project teams determine and achieve the optimal portfolio of quality characteristics
column47: and better articulate their value to all stakeholders. Thriving Systems Theory is an emerging framework of systems design quality that translates the research of design pattern patriarch Christopher Alexander on physical architecture design quality into the domain of systems engineering. The satisfaction achieved through agile methods is explained by Thriving Systems Theory's fifteen choice properties of systems design quality. We demonstrate by identifying the manifestation of the choice properties in SCRUM
column48: an exemplar of agile software project management. +//0Awv/9AKk- 2012 IEEE.+ACI-

column10: DASC 2011+ACI-
column38: +ACI-Software security patterns are a proven solution for recurring security problems. Security pattern catalogs are increasing rapidly. This creates difficulty in selecting appropriate software security patterns for a particular recurring security problem. There are several classification schemes to organize software security patterns. Every classification scheme has unique selection criteria for choosing a security pattern. However
column39: no classification scheme considers security flaws
column40: which is the root cause of software security vulnerabilities. In this paper
column41: we provide a natural classification scheme for software security patterns. Our classification scheme is associated with software lifecycle phases. Security flaws are incorporated in the classification of software security patterns with security objectives in the requirement phase
column42: security properties in the design phase
column43: and attack patterns in the implementation phase. Furthermore
column44: we enhance the existing security pattern template with classification parameters. +//0Awv/9AKk- 2011 IEEE.+ACI-

column38: +ACI-Behaviours are one of the most widely used features of Erlang/OTP. They offer a convenient and well+AC0-tested abstraction layer for frequently employed design patterns in concurrent Erlang programming. In effect
column39: they allow programmers to focus on the functional characteristics of their applications without having to resort to Erlang's concurrency+AC0-supporting primitives. However
column40: when it comes to ensuring that behaviours are properly used and callbacks are as expected
column41: the current Erlang/OTP compiler performs only minimal checks. This is no fault of the compiler though
column42: because most/all of the callbacks' API exists only in the documentation or the comments accompanying the code+ADs- as such
column43: it cannot always be trusted and it is almost impossible to have it mechanically processed. In this paper
column44: we propose a small extension to the language of function specifications of Erlang to allow the formal definition of the behaviours' callback API. We have implemented this extension on the development branch of Erlang/OTP and provide evidence of how it can be leveraged by static analysis tools such as Dialyzer to detect behaviour misuses. +//0Awv/9AKk- 2011 ACM.+ACI-
